summary: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) is referenced as a recipient of information in several CIA documents. These documents span from 1959 to 1970 and cover a range of topics, including the travel plans of individuals potentially associated with the USSR (Morris and Mollie Block), information on Haitian officials with possible ties to individuals connected to Lee Harvey Oswald (Jean K. Saurel and the de Mohrenschildts), and inquiries regarding the participation of prominent figures in the Australian Vietnam Moratorium Campaign. The FBI Director's role appears to be that of an intelligence recipient, suggesting the FBI was kept informed on matters of potential national security interest, including those that might peripherally relate to individuals later connected to the JFK assassination.
significance: The Director, FBI's significance in the JFK context is indirect. The documents suggest the FBI was an intelligence recipient on matters that, in retrospect, involve individuals who later became associated with the JFK assassination, such as George and Jeanne de Mohrenschildt through their connection to Jean K. Saurel. This indicates the FBI was aware of individuals and events that, while not directly related to the assassination at the time, later gained relevance in the context of the investigation.
